titleStmt.title: Unified Biometric Privacy Preserving Three-factor Authentication and Key Agreement for Cloud-assisted Autonomous Vehicles

analytic.title: Unified Biometric Privacy Preserving Three-factor Authentication and Key Agreement for Cloud-assisted Autonomous Vehicles

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TVT.2020.2971254, IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) are increasingly common, although there remain a number of limitations that need to be addressed in order for their deployment to be more widespread. For example, to mitigate the failure of self-driving functions in AVs, introducing the remote control capability (which allows a human driver to operate the vehicle remotely in certain circumferences) is one of several countermeasures proposed. However, the remote control capability breaks the isolation of onboard driving systems and can be potentially exploited by malicious actors to take over control of the AVs; thus, risking the safety of the passengers and pedestrians (e.g., AVs are remotely taken over by terrorist groups to carry out coordinated attacks in places of mass gatherings). Therefore, security is a key, mandatory feature in the design of AVs. In this paper, we propose a cloud-centric three-factor authentication and key agreement protocol (CT-AKA) integrating passwords, biometrics and smart cards to ensure secure access to both cloud and AVs. Three typical biometric encryption approaches, including fuzzy vault, fuzzy commitment, and fuzzy extractor, are unified to achieve three-factor authentication without leaking the biometric privacy of users. Moreover, two session keys are negotiated in our protocol, namely: one between the user and AV to support secure remote control of the AV, and the other is negotiated between the mobile device and the cloud to introduce resilience to the compromise of ephemeral security parameters to ensure cloud data access security with a high security guarantee. Finally, we formally verify the security properties and evaluate the efficiency of CT-AKA, whose findings demonstrate that the protocol achieves high security strength with reasonable computation and communication costs.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: As a recent technological trend in the automobile industry, autonomous vehicles (AVs) can potentially improve transportation safety, traffic efficiency and driving experience, as well as This work was supported in part by National Natural Science Foundation of China (61672413, U1708262, 61902290, 61772548, 61672415, 61671360, 61702404 and 61872449) and in part by China Postdoctoral Science Foundation Funded Project (2018M640962). (Corresponding author:Xindi Ma.) Qi Jiang, Jianfeng Ma and Xindi Ma are with School of Cyber Engineering, Xidian University, Xi'an, Shaanxi, China 710071, Email: jiangqixdu@gmail.com, jfma@mail.xidian.edu.cn, xdma@xidian.edu.cn.
Ning Zhang is with Texas A&M University at Corpus Christi, USA. Email: ning.zhang@ieee.org.
Jianbing Ni is with Department of Electrical and Computing Engineering, Queen's University, Kingston, ON, Canada, K7L 3N6. Email: jianbing.ni@queensu.ca.

K.-K. R. Choo is with the Department of Information Systems and Cyber Security, University of Texas at San Antonio, San Antonio, TX 78249-0631, USA. Email: raymond.choo@fulbrightmail.org reducing fuel consumption [1], [2], [3]. For example, an AV is capable of sensing unpredictable real-world environments, planning paths and actuating decisions without human intervention [4]. To support self-monitoring and decision making, multiple onboard sensors (e.g., cameras, radar, and LIDAR) produce a large quantity of data, such as real-time video streams [4]. It is estimated that the data generated from radar, LIDAR and camera is between 4-10 TB per day [5], and it is infeasible and uneconomical to install significant onboard computing and storage resources on each AV to store and process these data for autonomous driving. Therefore, cloudassisted AV (CAV) [4], [6], [7] was introduced to support autonomous driving, in order to achieve high levels of safety and traffic efficiency. Specifically, benefiting from advances in cloud computing and cloud storage technology, AVs acquire the storage and processing resources from the cloud to satisfy their data storage and analytical requirements [8], [9], and access relevant information (e.g., high-dimension maps, real-time traffic and machine learning models) from the AV manufacturers and autonomous driving service providers.

Remote control is envisioned to be a necessary feature in AVs, for example for pushing of security patches. Such a feature can also allow a human driver to take over control of the vehicles as required [10]. A number of AV companies, such as GM Cruise, Toyota, Zoox and Nissan, are reportedly planning to incorporate remote control in their vehicles, in order to facilitate decision-making particularly in complex situations [11]. In California, driverless testing without backup driver is allowed since 2018, only if the vehicles can be operated remotely 1 . Another way for remote control is via a user's mobile device, such as an Android or iOS device [12]. For example, the user is able to remotely lock or unlock the AV, or remotely turn on the heating/air-conditioning using an application installed on their devices [13].

Remote control, however, introduces a number of security risks as the onboard driving system is no longer isolated from the Internet. For example, a number of researchers have highlighted the potential for a malicious actor to identify and exploit vulnerability(ies) in the remote control mechanism and take over control of the vehicle [14], [15]. While unauthorized access to an AV and the cloud can potentially result in the leakage of sensitive information and the loss of the control over the AV, they could also result in physical damage and fatalities [12], [16]. For instance, as pointed out in [16], there is a risk that AVs can be remotely controlled by terrorist groups to participate in coordinated attacks, for example by driving AVs into places of mass gatherings. Thus, it is imperative to ensure that only legal users have the rights to access the cloud and their AVs. That is, secure channels should be established among the AV, the user, and the cloud, to prevent unauthorized individuals (e.g., adversary) from carrying out illicit / malicious activities such as eavesdropping, interception, tampering, and forgery (including false data injection) [17], [18], [19]. One key solution is to deploy authentication and key agreement (AKA) protocols for CAV systems.

Due to the potential life-threatening threats, the CAV system should impose strict security requirements during information exchange among users, the cloud and AVs [20], [21], [22]. However, it is widely recognized that each category of authentication factors has their inherent weaknesses, and a single factor authentication cannot provide sufficient security required for autonomous driving. Specifically, the knowledge factor, such as passwords, has low entropy and suffers from dictionary attacks. The possession factor, such as a smart card, can be lost. As for inherence factor, such as an individual's biometric, the leakage of its samples placed at a smart card or server can result in serious, and non-revocable threats to user privacy, as biometric features cannot be updated or replaced for the affected individuals [23], [24]. Thus, three-factor AKA (3FAKA) protocols are a promising way to achieve high security level, in which identity-confirming credentials from all three categories are combined to realize user authentication [25].

However, a naive integration of the three authentication factors can also result in a system that simply inherits the individual weakness from each factor. Hence, one of the greatest challenges in the design of 3FAKA protocols is to address the related weaknesses simultaneously and leverage the advantages of each factor. To preserve biometric privacy, for example, three typical biometric encryption approaches (fuzzy commitment [26], fuzzy vault [27] and fuzzy extractor [28]), have been applied in 3FAKA protocols. Note that, how to design a generic 3FAKA framework encompassing all three biometric encryption approaches is an understudied topic.

In this paper, we are partly inspired by the approaches of Zhao [29] and Yang et al. [30], and propose a cloud-centric 3FAKA protocol (CT-AKA) to establish security channels among AVs, users and the cloud to facilitate secure information exchange in the CAV system. The contributions of this paper are two-fold:

• To achieve three-factor authentication with biometric privacy preservation, the proposed 3FAKA protocol is based on generic biometric encryption, which unifies three typical biometric encryption approaches, i.e., fuzzy vault, fuzzy commitment, and fuzzy extractor. Moreover, user identity is concealed during the process to attain anonymity and untraceability. • Session keys (SKs) are negotiated among three entities, i.e., the user, cloud, and AV, to realize secure information exchange and prevent AVs from being remotely con-trolled by adversaries. Furthermore, a high security level, i.e. X-security, is guaranteed that the SK between user and cloud is resilient to the compromise of ephemeral security parameters. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. We review existing works related to AVs and 3FAKA in Section II. We present the model of CAV and design goals in Section III. Then, we provide the preliminaries of biometric authentication and propose CT-AKA in Section IV. We analyze the security and efficiency of CT-AKA in Section V and VI, respectively. Specifically, we demonstrate the security of CT-AKA with an automated cryptographic protocol verifier, ProVerif [31], and demonstrate that CT-AKA possesses more desired security properties than two other competing protocols. In addition, we show that the efficiency of CT-AKA is acceptable. We then conclude this work in the final section.

div.head: II. RELATED LITERATURE
div.p: We briefly review the related AV security literature, and revisit several existing AKA protocols.

div.head: A. CAV Security
div.p: A small number of literature reviews and surveys focusing on the security of autonomous and connected vehicles have been reported in recent years [12], [32], [33], [34], [35]. Becsi et al. [12], summarized the possible vulnerabilities and threats of connected vehicles from three aspects. The first aspect is the vehicle itself, which consists of three components, namely: electronic control units (ECUs), in-vehicle networks, and the gateway of standardized public communications (including 3G/4G, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth). The second aspect is the connection of a mobile device to the vehicle, and the third aspect is the communication technologies used by the vehicle to communicate with external environment. Petit and Shladover [36] listed various attack surfaces associated with autonomous and connected vehicles, and Parkinson et al. [37] reviewed the cyber security vulnerabilities of connected and autonomous vehicles. Specifically, Parkinson et al. focused on the following two categories: one resulting from and affecting the physical vehicles, and the other originating from connection, mechanisms and infrastructure. Thing and Wu [38] reiterated that the AV is more vulnerable to cyber threats than conventional vehicle due to the increased exterior communication between the AV and the outside, and the increased interior communications among systems inside it. They further presented a comprehensive taxonomy of AV attacks and defenses. Amoozadeh et al. [39] discussed the cyber-attacks on communication channels using simulation and the impact on cooperative vehicle stream caused by sensor tampering. Wyglinski et al. [40] categorized potential attacks of autonomous vehicles into physical attacks (e.g., to access or tamper a physical vehicle), close-proximity attacks (e.g., to obfuscate sensor information and to inject faults in ECUs within a range of approximately 10 meters), and remote attacks, including accessing ECUs and sensors via insecure communication paths over remote wireless access. Siri et al. [41] proposed a decentralized trust management scheme for vehicular networks which combines direct trust and indirect trust.

Currently, several existing authentication protocols have been proposed to secure in-vehicle networks. A broadcast authentication scheme exploiting key chains was designed in [42], where the symmetric cryptographic algorithm is leveraged to design key chain. Woo et al. [43] suggested combining symmetric encryption and keyed-hash message authentication code to protect controller area network (CAN) communications. Moreover, they used elliptic curve (EC) Diffie-Hellman exchange to achieve secure communication with an external device. Woo et al. [44] further leveraged an existing authenticated key exchange protocol to distribute session keys, and AES and HMAC to achieve confidentiality and authenticity. Most recently, Mundhenk et al. [45] presented lightweight authentication for secure automotive networks, referred to as LASAN. Unfortunately, these aforementioned schemes are not intended for securing remote access to AVs and the cloud.
Although the security and privacy of CAN and external communication have been well-investigated, how to ensure secure remote access to the CAV system has not been studied.

div.head: B. Authentication and Key Agreement
div.p: AKA, as a primary method to secure network access, is extensively deployed to verify the claimed identity of communicating parties and build secure communication channels. To eliminate the weaknesses in each authentication factor, 3FAKA holds great potential to secure remote access in the CAV system. The development of 3FAKA protocols falls into two stages according to whether the biometric privacy is protected or not.

In the first stage, biometric template is placed at a smart card or server directly [46]. However, if the biometric data is disclosed, it will cause serious threats to the privacy of individuals [47].

In the second stage, different biometric encryption approaches [26], [27], [28] are leveraged to achieve biometric privacy protection. Fan and Lin [48] presented a 3FAKA protocol based on fuzzy commitment, where a random string is selected and combined with the biometric template, while this protocol fails to support user password change and smart card revocation. Huang et al. [49] introduced a generic approach of upgrading two-factor AKA (2FAKA) protocols to 3FAKA using fuzzy extractor. Similar to Huang et al.'s work, Yu et al. [50] presented the fuzzy vault based 3FAKA framework and a concrete 3FAKA on the basis of a 2FAKA. Jiang et al. [51] proposed a 3FAKA protocol between users and the cloud based on fuzzy extractor, which is a two-party protocol unsuitable for three-party CAV systems. Das et al.

[52] designed a three-party 3FAKA protocol, but it cannot provide several key security features. Li et al. [53] proposed an anonymous 3FAKA protocol for medical sensor systems, where a fuzzy extractor is adopted to protect user's biometric features. Unfortunately, Li et al.'s protocol cannot provide perfect forward secrecy (PFS) and is vulnerable to the leakage of ephemeral parameters. Jiang et al. [54] proposed a 3FAKA protocol for cloud assisted wearable devices based on fuzzy extractor. This protocol also cannot attain PFS and X-security. Wu et al. [55] introduced an anonymous 3FAKA protocol for cloud-assisted wearable devices, which only employs hash function. Nonetheless, it is widely recognized that any password-based authentication protocol without involving public key operations is vulnerable to offline password guessing attacks (OFPGAs).

To preserve biometric privacy, it is desirable to propose a 3FAKA protocol from generic biometric encryption to unify these different biometric encryption approaches in CAV systems. Moreover, due to the strict security requirements of the CAV systems, it is necessary to identify specific security goals and design proper 3FAKA protocols to prevent malicious remote access.

div.head: III. SYSTEM MODEL AND SECURITY GOALS
div.p: In this section, we will present the system model of cloudassisted AV systems and identify the security goals.

div.head: A. CAV Model
div.p: The system model of a conventional AV is composed of three basic modules, including sensing, planning and control. The sensing module perceives the static and dynamic environment by various sensors, such as GPS, radar, LIDAR and camera. The planning module obtains sensory information from sensors, and then generates usable information about its environment and plans driving paths. The planning module passes the information and decisions to control module actuating the AV [4], [6].

Since these onboard sensors produce real-time data streams at high data rates (often at GB/s), it is of great challenge for AVs to store and process all these sensor data in real time [4]. To address this issue, cloud is integrated into the AV control system, as is shown in Fig. 1. The cloud-assisted AV systems incorporate sensors and network connectivity to enable remote monitoring and control of AV. The typical communications in a CAV system can be divided into two types [13]: 1) automotive bus systems to support in-vehicle communications; and 2) wireless communication systems (e.g. Wi-Fi, 4G, 5G) enabling an AV to communicate with external entities including the cloud and users. As shown in Fig. 1, the entities of CAV system include the cloud, AVs, and users.
• The AV is equipped with sensors, ECUs and in-vehicle networks, as well as an onboard unit (OBU), which is an embedded or a standalone hardware/software component.

The OBU is connected to cloud center via cellular base station (BS) or WiFi access point (AP). Onboard planning module interacts with the cloud planning module for planning paths and passes useful information and decisions to the control module, which actuates the AV as planned [4]. • The cloud is responsible for data storage, data analysis and path planning. It maintains a variety of data for AVs, such as multi-dimensional maps, weather conditions, and traffic information. Specifically, the cloud collects realtime traffic information, road conditions, machine learning models and environmental data from sensors on AVs and analyzes them for situational awareness. Finally, the cloud performs decision-making and road planning to assist AVs moving on roads [4], [56].
• The user monitors and controls the AV remotely. Specifically, the user can check the status of the AV on cloud and control the starting and stopping of the AV remotely.
It also can communicate with the AV for locking or unlocking through direct connections, e.g., Bluetooth, Wi-Fi and NFC.

div.head: B. Security Goals
div.p: Network connectivity of AVs with external entities, including the cloud and users, increases the attack surface of an AV and the probability of being remotely attacked. The in-vehicle devices, such as the sensors and ECUs, which are not intended to be linked to external networks, may be compromised via remote exploitation [37]. Besides, the monitoring and control of AVs can expose them to potential cyber threats. An attacker may take control of an AV and disrupt its various features and functions without having hands-on access to it [57]. Further, a compromised AV may be controlled to cause certain damage or accidents remotely and invisibly [6]. On the other hand, the data collected from the AV may contain potentially sensitive information (e.g. position data, operational information, etc.), and the cloud may be prone to unauthorized access. One of the major causes of the above attacks is that communication may be eavesdropped, spoofed, modified, or replayed. To secure the transmitted data, all communicating entities must be authenticated and the data should be encrypted to prevent unauthorized access to AVs. Therefore, the AKA mechanisms become mandatory to ensure that only authorized entities are permitted to participate in the CAV systems.

Since cyber attacks on AVs may cause physical damage and loss of human lives, security requirements have become more critical in the CAV system. Single factor authentication is not sufficient to ensure CAV system security. 3FAKA protocol is a promising solution to secure the CAV systems. In this paper, the adversary is allowed to obtain any two of the three factors but not all three factors at the same time, please refer to [54] for more details. Accordingly, this work aims at proposing a 3-factor security protocol for CAV with the following goals [58], [59], [60].

• SG1. Mutual Authentication: To assure only legitimate entities have access to the cloud and AV, as well as to defend against malicious attacks, an entity should be able to prove he/she is the person claims to be. • SG2. SK Agreement: SKs should be generated for symmetric key primitives that ensures data commnunication security among the user, the cloud, and the AV. • SG3. Known SK Security: Both the SKs between the cloud and user, and between the AV and user in the different sessions should be independent. That is, the SK of one session should not be derived even if these SKs of previous sessions are revealed by the adversary. • SG4. Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS): The SKs between the cloud and user should provide PFS to ensure data security in the case that the private keys of the cloud and users are revealed. Specifically, the SKs negotiated before should not be derived in this case [29]. • SG5. X-security: The SK established in the protocol should be resilient to the exposure of ephemeral security parameters, i.e., Diffie-Hellman parameter. That is, the Diffie-Hellman parameter in a session will not expose the SK [29]. • SG6. User Anonymity: To conceal user identity, the protocol should be capable of preserving user anonymity, i.e., the adversaries except the user and the intended counterpart cannot identify the real user identity through capturing the authentication transcripts. • SG7. User Untraceability: The protocol is strong enough to assure identity privacy, even the user's action can be traced by the attacker through identifying an invariant in the authentication message, which may be used to link the authentication transcripts of different sessions [61]. The protocol should be capable of providing user untraceability. • SG8. Biometric Privacy Protection: The biometric samples placed at the smart card or server may cause serious privacy risks once being leaked. To preserve biometric privacy, no biometric samples should be placed at the server or the smart card. • SG9. No Password Verifier Table : A database for storing user password or its derived value may lead to the disclosure of user password. To relieve the risk of server compromise, no sensitive value related with user password should be maintained on the server. • SG10. No Password Exposure: The privileged insider may use a user's password of the current system to access the account of the user in other systems, in which the same password is used. To alleviate this risk, the password or its direct hash values should not be presented to the server in the registration phase. • SG11. Timely Typo Detection: When an error is made in entering a password, the user has to wait for a relatively long period for the notification from the cloud. To be more user friendly and enhance login efficiency, the user should be notified timely in this case. • SG12. Sound Repairability: Since smart cards are prone to being lost or stolen, the protocol should provide good repairability when revoking a smart card. That is, the card owner is able to revoke his/her card without the identity change. • SG13. No Smart Card Loss Attack: The protocol should be immune from OFPGAs even in the case that the secret parameters in the card has been extracted. • SG14. Three-factor Security: The protocol remains secure even though any two of the three factors are compromised. Concretely, one of the challenging issues is that the protocol should be secure against OFPGAs when the card and biometrics are compromised.

div.head: IV. CT-AKA PROTOCOL
div.p: In this section, we will review the preliminary, i.e., biometric encryption, and propose the CT-AKA protocol.

div.head: A. Biometric Encryption
div.p: Biometrics, including one's physiological characteristics (e.g., fingerprint and iris), behavioral patterns and gestures, have been widely adopted for authentication purposes. The authentication process has two phases: enrollment and verification. Biometric template is enrolled in the first phase, and then, a captured biometric sample is compared with the enrolled template to authenticate the user in the second phase [24]. Biometric features cannot be updated in the lifetime of individuals, such that the leakage of biometric samples placed at the smart card or server can cause serious threats to user privacy. To protect biometric privacy, many template protection techniques have been developed based on biometric encryption, cancelable biometric, and secure computation. In this paper, we mainly focus on those based on biometric encryption, i.e., fuzzy commitment, fuzzy vault, and fuzzy extractor [30].

1) Fuzzy commitment: In the enrollment phase, a template α = bk -bio is generated, where bk denotes the random key and bio denotes the biometric sample. In the verification phase, given another sample bio , bk can be retrieved as f (α+bio ) = f (bk + (bio -bio)), where f is an error correction function. If the distance between bio and bio is less than the correction capacity δ, bk can be recovered.

2) Fuzzy vault: In the enrollment phase, a polynomial is generated based on a random key bk, and a biometric sample bio is projected on the polynomial to derive a set of points. The set of projected points and a set of chaff points serve as the template. In the verification phase, given a biometric sample bio , the polynomial can be re-constructed if bio largely overlaps with bio, which in turn enables the recovery of bk.

3) Fuzzy extractor: In the enrollment process, a biometric sample bio is used as input to generate a secret key bk and an auxiliary string aus, which serves as the template. In the verification process, bk can be extracted from aus and another biometric sample bio if bio and bio are sufficiently approximate.

4) Unified abstraction: A unified abstraction of three typical biometric encryption based biometric privacy protection approach is presented in [30]. Let BIO denote the space of a particular biometric feature. These three approaches can be described as the following two algorithms: (bk, tp) ← KeyT P Gen(bio): The probabilistic key and template generation algorithm outputs a key bk and a template tp, taking as input a biometric sample bio ∈ BIO.

bk ← KeyRel(tp, bio ): The deterministic key release algorithm takes as input a template tp and a biometric sample bio , and outputs a key bk . bk and bk will be equal if bio and bio are sufficiently approximate.

div.head: B. CT-AKA
div.p: CT-AKA consists of 6 phases: system setup, AV registration, user registration, user authentication, password and biometrics change, and smart card revocation. In setup phase, the cloud bootstraps the CAV system and releases system parameters. In AV registration phase, the cloud generates and distributes a secret key for each AV. In user registration phase, the cloud issues a smart card storing the secret key to each user. In the phase of user authentication, the 3FAKA mechanism is executed to verify the user identity and build secure channels among the cloud, the AV and the user. Notations in the CT-AKA are listed in Table I.

1) System Setup: The cloud C firstly generates G of the order q, picks P , k ⊆ Z * q , s ⊆ Z * q , outputs (s, S = sP ), releases the parameters (P, S, h), l 0 is a medium integer determining the capacity of fuzzy verifier against online guessing [58]. C also selects an identity CID.

2) AV Registration: In this phase, to build the trust with C, an AV AV j first selects its identity, which can be the vehicle plate number, and sends the identity V ID j to C. Upon receiving V ID j , C picks up a random number r j , computes vk j = h(V ID j ||k||r j ), and stores < V ID j , r j > into the 0018-9545 (c) 2019 IEEE. This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI database. Then, C distributes vk j to AV j in a secure way, and AV j stores vk j in a secure storage.
3) User Registration: Each user U i builds the trust with C and obtains a smart card in a secure way, see Fig. 2.
• Step UR 1 : U i first presents his/her chosen identity U ID i and personal credential (i.e., the scanned copy of the driving license, or identity card) to C.
div.formula: • Step UR 2 : C picks up a random number r i , computes a = h(U ID i ||k||r i ) and b = h(SCN i ||k), stores < U ID i , SCN i , r i , Credential > into the database.
div.p: Next, C delivers the smart card containing the parameters < a, b, P, S, l 0 , KeyT P Gen(), KeyRel(), h() > to U i . • Step UR 3 : U i inputs < U ID i , P W i , bio i >, and the card runs the biometric key and template generation algorithm (bk i , tp i ) = KeyT P Gen(bio i ) , and computes
div.formula: A = a ⊕ h(U ID i ||P W i ||bk i ), B = b ⊕ h(U ID i ⊕ P W i ⊕ bk i ),
div.p: and c = h(h(U ID i ||P W i ||bk i ) mod l 0 ). Note that the value c acts as the fuzzy verifier for detecting a wrong password provided by the user while avoiding OFPGAs when the value c is exposed [58]. Finally, the parameters < A, B, c, tp i , P, S, l 0 , KeyT P Gen(), KeyRel(), h() > are stored in it. 4) User Authentication: To access the CAV system, U i inserts the card, and submits the password and biometrics < U ID i , P W i , bio i >, as is shown in Fig. 3.
• Step A 1 : The card runs the key release algorithm bk i = KeyRel(tp i , bio i ), and computes
div.formula: c = h(h(U ID i ||P W i ||bk i ) mod l 0 ). If c = c , this ses- sion is aborted; otherwise, it computes a = A ⊕ h(U ID i ||P W i ||bk i ), and b = B ⊕ h(U ID i ⊕ P W i ⊕ bk i ),
div.p: and randomly picks up a number x ⊆ Z * q , and n
div.formula: 1 . It continues computing X = xP , d = h(X||U ID i ||CID), M 1 = aP + dX, ps = (a + xd)S, e = h(U ID i ||a||b||n 1 ), pk = h(ps||M 1 ||CID), and M 2 = {U ID i ||X||e||V ID j }pk. Finally, U i sends M SG 1 =< M 1 , M 2 , n 1 > to C. • Step A 2 : After receiving M SG 1 from U i , C first computes ps = sM 1 , and pk = h(ps||M 1 ||CID).
div.p: It uses pk to decrypt M 2 to get U ID i , X, e, V ID j , and retrieves SCN i , r i according to
div.formula: U ID i . Next, it computes a = h(U ID i ||k||r i ), b = h(SCN i ||k), d = h(X||U ID i ||CID), e = h(U ID i ||a||b||n 1 )
div.p: , and M 1 = aP + dX. C accepts U i as a legitimate user if e = e and M 1 = M 1 ; otherwise, it rejects the authentication request and terminates. C continues to generate y ⊆ Z * q and n 2 . It then computes Y = yP , psk = yX, the session key ucsk = h(U ID i ||CID||X||Y ||pk||a||psk) shared with U i . Then, C proceeds to retrieve r j according to V ID j , and computes the secret values vk j = h(V ID j ||k||r j ) and
div.formula: tk j = h(U ID i ||V ID j ||CID||psk||n 2 ). After that, C computes M 3 = {U ID i ||V ID j ||CID||tk j ||n 1 ||n 2 }vk j and M 4 = h(U ID i ||V ID j ||CID||tk j ||n 1 ||n 2 ||vk j ). Fi- nally, it sends M SG 2 =< M 3 , M 4 > to AV j . • Step A 3 : Upon receiving M SG

div.p: Password and Biometrics Change: U i can update the password and the biometrics locally.
• Step C 1 : U i inserts the card, and submits the password and biometrics < U ID i , P W i , bio i >. The card runs the key release algorithm bk i = KeyRel(tp i , bio i ),
div.formula: and computes c = h(h(U ID i ||P W i ||bk i ) mod l 0 ). If c = c, this session is aborted; otherwise, it computes a = A ⊕ h(U ID i ||P W i ||bk i ), and b = B ⊕ h(U ID i ⊕ P W i ⊕ bk i ). • Step C 2 : After obtaining a new password P W n i and biometrics bio n i from U i , the card computes (bk n i , tp n i ) = KeyT P Gen(bio n i ), A n = a ⊕ h(U ID i ||P W n i ||bk n i ), B n = b ⊕ h(U ID i ⊕ P W n i ⊕ bk n i ), and c n = h(h(U ID i ||P W n i ||bk n i ) mod l 0 ). • Step C 3 : The card replaces < A, B, c, tp i > with < A n , B n , c n ,

div.p: Fig. 3. The Authentication Phase of CT-AKA registration and performed in a secure manner as follows.

• U i first presents the identity U ID i and his/her credential to C. C verifies U i 's credential. If they are valid, C generates a random number r n i , computes a = h(U ID i ||k||r n i ) and b = h(SCN n i ||k), and updates the old entry < U ID i , SCN i , r i , Credential > with the new entry < U ID i , SCN n i , r n i , Credential >; otherwise, C drops the request.
• The remaining steps are the same as that of user registration phase.

div.head: V. SECURITY ANALYSIS
div.p: In this section, we will show that CT-AKA is secure through comprehensive inspection against security goals mentioned in Section III.B. Specifically, we use the Proverif v1.97 [31] to reason about the security of CT-AKA, and compare it with two state-of-the-art protocols.

div.head: A. Analysis of Security Goals
div.p: The proposed CT-AKA attains all security goals mentioned in Section III.B.

div.head: 1) Mutual Authentication:
div.p: We explain how users, AVs, and the cloud realize mutual authentication in CT-AKA.

• C authenticates U i through the validation of e = h(U ID i ||a||b||n 1 ). The adversary Adv pretending U i has to provide a legal value e. Therefore, Adv cannot compute such a value without possessing U i 's password, biometric, or the value A and B stored in the smart card.
div.formula: • AV j authenticates C through the validation of M 4 = h(U ID i ||V ID j ||CID||tk j ||n 1 ||n 2 ||vk j )
div.p: , where vk j is secret only known by AV j and C. • Similarly, C authenticates AV j through the validation of sion key uvsk = h(U ID i ||V ID j ||tk j ||n 1 ||n 3 ) is established between U i and AV j , which is computed using tk j only known by them. AV j and C establishes the session key vcsk = h(V ID j ||CID||n 2 ||n 3 ||vk j ), which is computed with vk j only known by them. Thus, the proposed CT-AKA supports session key agreement.
div.formula: M 5 = h(U ID i ||V ID j ||CID||tk j ||n 2 ||n 3 ||vk j ).
div.p: 3) Known Session Key Security: As for the SK ucsk between U i and C, its generation involves the session specific values X and Y , which are randomly selected in each session. In the case that a session key ucsk is compromised by Adv, Adv cannot obtain the secret values pk and a due to irreversibility of hash function h(). In turn, Adv cannot compute ucsk in other sessions. Similarly, Adv cannot compute the secret value tk j . Thus, uvsk in another session remains secure even if uvsk in a session is exposed to Adv. In short, the proposed CT-AKA achieves known key security.

4) Perfect Forward Secrecy: For CT-AKA, U i has three long term secret values i.e., A = a ⊕ h(U ID i ||P W i ||bk i ), P W i and bio i . C has the long term secrets secret values s and k. In each session, x and y are randomly generated. It is hard to compute psk = xyP with X = xP and Y = yP , due to the difficulty of EC computational Diffie-Hellman (ECCDH) problem. As a result, the disclosure of these long term secrets will not lead to the exposure of ucsk = h(U ID i ||CID||X||Y ||pk||a||psk) in the previous sessions.

5) X-security: In CT-AKA, even if the DH-exponent x ⊆ Z * q in a session is exposed, the session key ucsk = h(U ID i ||CID||X||Y ||pk||a||psk) established in this session will still be secure. A critical component in the computation of ucsk is pk = h(ps||M 1 ||CID) , where ps = (a + xd)S . If x is revealed, the adversary cannot compute ps without knowing a, which is stored in the card and protected by user password and biometrics. Many state-of-the-art protocols [52], [53] fail to achieve this salient feature.

6) User Anonymity: Adv first captures all the authentication messages. In CT-AKA, U i 's identity U ID i is included in the field M 2 = {U ID i ||X||e||V ID j }pk in M SG 1 . One way for Adv to get U ID i is to use s of C to compute ps = sM 1 , which is impossible since s is a secret only konwn by C. The other way for Adv to obtain U ID i is to use the values x and a to compute ps = (a + xd)S, which is also impossible for Adv thanks to the hardness of ECCDH problem. Moreover, it is also hard to obtain a, since it is stored in the card and protected by user password and biometrics. Hence, the proposed CT-AKA supports user anonymity.

7) User Untraceability: Adv first collects user authentication messages and links two sessions with the same field to trace a user U i . In the authentication phase, there are two messages involving U i , i.e., M SG 1 =< M 1 , M 2 , n 1 >, and M SG 4 =< Y, M 6 , n 2 , n 3 >. We note that each field is a dynamic value or derived from random values, which are randomly selected in each session. That is, there is no field, which can be used to link the sessions of a user. Thus, the proposed CT-AKA supports user untraceability.

8) Biometric Privacy Protection: In CT-AKA, user biometric samples are processed locally in the client side, such that C maintains no information related to user biometrics. Moreover, the information related to user biometrics stored the smart card is first converted by the biometric encryption algorithms from biometrics and then derived from hash function. This information does not endanger biometric privacy, even if it is leaked. Therefore, the proposed CT-AKA supports biometric privacy protection.

div.head: 9) No Password Verifier Table:
div.p: In CT-AKA, the user information maintained by C includes < U ID i , SCN i , r i , Credential >, which has no derived value from user passwords. Therefore, the CT-AKA does not need verifier table.

10) No Password Exposure: In the user registration phase of CT-AKA, U i sends U ID i to C. C obtains no information related to user password and is unable to derive user password. Thus, the password is not exposed to C. CT-AKA satisfies the goal of no password exposure.

11) Timely Typo Detection: In CT-AKA, U i inputs the password when login, the smart card computes the fuzzy verifier c = h(h(U ID i ||P W i ||bk i ) mod l 0 ), and compares it with the value c stored in it. If U i enters a wrong password mistakenly, the verification will fail and the user will be timely notified.
12) Sound Rrepairability:

The user information < U ID i , SCN i , r i , Credential > is maintained on C. A user can invoke the process of smart card revocation to revoke a smart card, in which the value SCN i can be updated without the identity change. Thus, the proposed CT-AKA supports sound repairability.
13) No Smart Card Loss Attacks: We explain why CT-AKA is immune from this attack below.

• In the password and biometrics change phase of CT-AKA, a fuzzy verifier acts a first line of defence to reject the illegal password and biometrics change request from Adv getting U i 's card. Thus, Adv cannot change password at will.
div.formula: * = h(h(U ID * i ||P W * i ||bk i ) mod l 0 )
div.p: , the pair may still be rejected by C since c is a "fuzzy verifier".
div.formula: • Suppose Adv could capture the message M SG 1 =< M 1 , M 2 , n 1 >, where A = a ⊕ h(U ID i ||P W i ||bk i ), B = b ⊕ h(U ID i ⊕ P W i ⊕ bk i ), M 1 = aP + dX, and M 2 = {U ID i ||X||e||V ID j }pk. Adv can derive a * = A ⊕ h(U ID * i ||P W * i ||bk * i ), b * = B ⊕ h(U ID * i ⊕ P W * i ⊕ bk * i ),
= a ⊕ h(U ID i ||P W i ||bk i ), and B = b ⊕ h(U ID i ⊕ P W i ⊕ bk i )
div.p: , and runs the key release algorithm to obtain bk i . Without the password, the adversary cannot retrieve the correct values a and b.

div.head: B. Formal Verification with ProVerif
div.p: ProVerif [31] is an automatic cryptographic protocol verifier. The authentication phase of CT-AKA is rewritten as Horn clauses and modeled in Pi Calculus, from which it can then validate the properties of authentication and secrecy in the Dolev-Yao setting. CT-AKA is represented by a total of 190 lines of code, and Proverif verifies mutual authentication between users, the cloud and AVs, as well as the secrecy of the session key they have negotiated. The results demonstrate that CT-AKA achieves session key secrecy and mutual authentication between the entities.

div.head: C. Comparison of Achieved Security Goals
div.p: Table II summarizes the comparison results of CT-AKA with existing works in [52] and [53]. As given in Table II, both protocols in [52], [53] are incapable of achieving all the security goals. Specifically, protocols in [52], [53] cannot guarantee SG5, SG12, SG13 as well as SG14. Furthermore, the protocol in [53] is unable to realize the security goal SG4. Taking all these aspects into consideration, CT-AKA is the only one that achieves all the desirable security goals, therefore, it fits for CAV better than these existing protocols.

div.head: VI. EFFICIENCY ANALYSIS
div.p: We evaluate the efficiency of CT-AKA from two aspects, i.e., the computational time and communication cost. The following notations are used to denote the operational time of cryptographic primitives.

T ecm : the time of EC multiplication; T eca : the time of EC point addition; T s : the time of symmetric encryption/decryption; T h : the time of executing hash. We simulated the CAV system consisting of a smart phone, a laptop computer acting as the AV, and a desktop computer acting as the cloud. The configuration of each entity is given in Table III. The primitives are realized in Java and the executing time are listed in Table IV. Table V summarizes the comparison of CT-AKA and the existing works in [52], [53]. Although CT-AKA incurs more computational burden than those in [52] and [53] on the cloud, its overall computational cost is lower than that of the approach in [52], while it is higher than that of the protocol in [53]. For AVs, the time cost to achieve AKA in CT-AKA is less than that in both the protocols in [52] and [53].

Furthermore, we reveal that CT-AKA is still efficient when the number of users is large. For instance, a large number of AVs will be started simultaneously at the end of a big social event, resulting in a large number of authentication messages received by the cloud. Fig. 4 shows the running time for dealing with the authentication messages on smart phones, cloud and AVs. The proposed CT-AKA is much more efficient than the protocol in [52] for authentication message generation and key agreement for the smart phone. Although CT-AKA needs more time for the cloud to respond authentication messages compared with the protocols in [52], [53], the time cost of the cloud is still in the acceptable range, i.e., 8 seconds for 1000 authentication messages.

To evaluate communication cost, it is assumed that the lengths of identity, nonce, hash output, and an EC point are 128, 128, 160, and 1024 bits, respectively. Table VI compares CT-AKA with the protocols in [52] and [53] As given in Table II, both protocols in [52], [53] are incapable of achieving all the security goals. Taking all these aspects into consideration, CT-AKA fits for CAV better than these existing protocols.

div.head: VII. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we proposed a cloud-centric 3FAKA protocol to attain AKA among AVs, cloud and users in a CAV system. By unifying three typical biometric privacy protection approaches, (i.e., fuzzy vault, fuzzy commitment, and fuzzy extractor), CT-AKA can achieve three-factor authentication (i.e., password, smart card and biometric) to enable users to achieve authentication while preserving the privacy of their identity and biometrics. Through both mutual authentication and key agreement, secure channels are established to secure the communications among the cloud, the user and the AV for preventing AVs from being maliciously controlled by attackers. Furthermore, we offered strong security guarantees for the communication between the cloud and the users, which is also shown to be resilient to the compromise of ephemeral security parameters.

For the future work, we will extend the proposed protocol to also provide a one-time ticket for pick-up services in autonomous driving, as well as implement and evaluate a prototype of the proposed approach.

Hence, U i and C are mutually authenticated. 2) Session Key Agreement: In the authentication phase, U i and C negotiate ucsk = h(U ID i ||CID||X||Y ||pk||a||psk). The computation of ucsk involves three secret values pk, psk and a, which are only known by U i and C. The ses-

figure.figDesc: 2 , AV j decrypts M 3 using the secret key vk j , and computesM 4 = h(U ID i ||V ID j ||CID||tk j ||n 1 ||n 2 ||vk j ). If M 4 = M 4, AV j aborts the session; otherwise, it selects a nonce n 3 and computes vcsk = h(V ID j ||CID||n 2 ||n 3 ||vk j ), which is shared between the cloud and vk j . Next, it computes the session key uvsk = h(U ID i ||V ID j ||tk j ||n 1 ||n 3 ) shared between U i and AV j . Then, it computes the authenticator M 5 = h(U ID i ||V ID j ||CID||tk j ||n 2 ||n 3 ||vk j ) to prove its identity, and sends M SG 3 =< n 3 , M 5 > to C.

note.p: • Step A 4 : After receiving M SG 3 , C computes M 5 = h(U ID i ||V ID j ||CID||tk j ||n 2 ||n 3 ||vk j ) to check the identity of AV j . If M 5 = M 5 ,it aborts the session; otherwise, it computes vcsk = h(V ID j ||CID||n 2 ||n 3 ||vk j ) shared with AV j . Then, it computes the authenticator M 6 = h(U ID i ||CID||Y ||pk||a||psk||n 1 ||n 2 ||n 3 ) to prove its legitimacy. Finally, it sends M SG 4 =< Y, M 6 , n 2 , n 3 > to U i . • Step A 5 : Upon receiving M SG 4 , U i computes psk = xY , M 6 = h(U ID i ||CID||Y ||pk||a||psk||n 1 ||n 2 ||n 3 ), and accepts that the cloud is legal if M 6 = M 6 ; otherwise, it terminates this authentication session. It continues to compute tk j = h(U ID i ||V ID j ||CID||psk||n 2 ), the session key ucsk = h(U ID i ||CID||X||Y ||pk||a||psk) shared with C and the session key uvsk = h(U ID i ||V ID j ||CID||tk j ||n 1 ||n 3 ) shared with AV j .

figure.figDesc: ||P W i ||bk i ) mod l 0 ). Even if both the card and biometrics are compromised, Adv has to guess U ID * i and P W * i . However, even if Adv has got a pair U ID * i and P W * i satifying c = c * where c

figure.figDesc: and e * = h(U ID * i ||a * ||b * ||n 1 ), where A and B are extracted from U i 's card. Thanks to the hardness of EC-CDH, Adv still cannot calculate e = h(U ID i ||a||b||n 1 ) from the value M 2 = {U ID i ||X||e||V ID j }pk. Therefore, Adv is unable to calculate e, which is a necessity to validate U ID * i and P W * i . Above all, CT-AKA offers the resistance to smart card loss attacks, including unauthorized password and biometrics change,

CT-AKA employs three factors to achieve the authentication of the user, i.e., password, biometric and smart card. Even if any two of the three factors are compromised, the protocol is still secure. Concretely, if both the smart card and biometrics are compromised, the protocol is still a secure password based authentication protocol. The adversary obtains the values A

in terms of communication cost. In CT-AKA, the messages M SG 1 , M SG 2 , M SG 3 , and M SG 4 have the length of (1024 + 128 + 1024 + 160 + 128 + 128) = 2592, (128 + 128 + 128 + 160 + 128 + 128 + 160) = 960, (128 + 160) = 288, (1024 + 160 + 128 + 128) = 1440 bits, respectively. The total communication cost of CT-AKA is 5152 bits. The total communication costs of Das et al.'s and Li et al.'s protocols are 5472 bits and 3904 bits, respectively. The total communication cost of CT-AKA is lower than that of Das et al.'s protocol, while it is higher than that of Li et al.'s protocol.
